And Maclean decided to go with 
Burgess as well.

2580.34.text:
The third man was a very topical subject 
at the time.

2582.95.text:
Grahame Greene had written his novella just
two years earlier

2586.69.text:
and here is the book which 
fairly rapidly became

2592.22.text: that very famous and classic film

2594.07.text: with Joseph Cotten and Orson Welles.

2597.94.text: And in fact there was an awful lot of speculation:

2600.59.text:
if in fact they had been tipped off, 
who had tipped them off?

2605.21.text: In fact, what happened was in 1956

2607.94.text:
they finally came out of hiding in Russia
and called a conference.

2611.78.text: And Maclean and Burgess, very proud of themselves,

2615.17.text:
explaining how they had been spying 
for Russia for years,

2617.44.text: gave the reasons why they had.

2619.31.text: They didn't reveal who had tipped them off

2621.36.text: or who the third man was.

2624.48.text: But there was one man, Colonel Marcus Lipton,

2627.30.text:
MP for Brixton, who asked questions 
in the House of Commons

2630.82.text:
where, as you know, you can't be done 
for libel.

2633.96.text:
And he named Kim Philby as the diplomat 
who he thought -

2638.81.text: he was by that time deputy head of MI6 -

2642.67.text: who he said had tipped off the two spies.

2645.72.text: And Harold McMillan had to make a statement...

2648.03.text:
By the way, just as we're looking 
at this photo,

2649.81.text: there is Kim Philby on the right

2651.79.text: and there is a keen young reporter,

2655.75.text: who only died a couple of years ago.

2658.69.text: And Harold McMillan - rather than saying,

2660.88.text: as prime ministers tend to say now,

2662.96.text: 'We do not comment on security matters,' -

2665.76.text: he said, 'There is no evidence whatever

2667.80.text:
that Kim Philby was in any way 
involved in either

2670.80.text:
spying for the Russians or 
being anything less than

2673.69.text:
a fine and upstanding member of 
our diplomatic service,'

2677.58.text:
which was a rather surprising thing 
for him to say.

2680.10.text: It seems to have been just that, again,

2683.06.text:
unless you can bring evidence and 
put someone on trial,

2685.62.text: you've got to assume they are innocent.

2687.69.text: And if you are asked a question in Parliament,

2690.77.text:
you've got to stick to the rules of 
not giving away

2694.96.text: might indicate they were doing anything.

2696.86.text:
So, this was Philby's triumphant 
press conference -

2699.83.text: which actually you can watch on YouTube,

2701.54.text:
there's a bit of film showing him 
smirking away, really,

2705.42.text:
while he replies to all the reporters, 
and saying at one point,

2708.93.text:
'The last time I spoke to anyone 
who was a Communist

2712.69.text:
and knowing him to be a Communist, 
was back in 1936'.

2715.93.text:
It was one of the biggest lies he told in
that particular interview

2720.42.text: but, anyway, we realised even back in 1956

2723.07.text:
that he must be a spy, 
we just couldn't prove it.

2726.32.text:
And so we stopped giving him 
any important work

2728.79.text: and he was demoted from deputy of MI6.

2732.36.text:
And after a few more years 
Philby himself decided

2734.67.text:
he wasn't getting anywhere and 
perhaps if somebody did denounce him,

2740.03.text: and so he, too, fled to Russia.

2746.08.text:
There was also, as you must know, 
a fourth person.

2749.62.text: It was this man, Sir Anthony Blunt,

2753.52.text: the surveyor of The Queen's pictures.

2755.95.text: And there he is with Her Majesty.

2757.65.text:
Anthony Blunt, who had in fact been a don
in the 1930s in Cambridge,

2763.56.text: and he was the man who in fact persuaded

2765.87.text:
Philby, Burgess and Maclean all to become
spies for Russia.

2772.58.text: even though we'd found out by 1963 that

2776.72.text: he had been spying for Russia as well.

2779.00.text: But when Andrew Boyle published his book,

2781.75.text:
he wrote a book called 
'Five Who Spied for Russia' -

2785.17.text:
here we have Kim Philby, 
Burgess and Maclean -

2789.57.text: and several people had told him that

2792.01.text: Sir Anthony Blunt was the fourth man.

2797.84.text: I will sue you for libel and the establishment

2800.87.text:
will stick to their agreement that 
they wouldn't admit anything like that.'

2806.51.text: And so he had to keep his identity secret.

2808.93.text:
But Mrs Thatcher when she came to power 
in 1979 as prime minster

2814.60.text:
had to be told that the fourth man was known
to be Sir Anthony Blunt.

2818.81.text: And she really felt that allowing him

2820.85.text: to stay there as surveyor of the pictures,

2822.85.text: keeping his knighthood and all the rest

2824.41.text: when he had been spying for Russia,

2826.01.text: was just a bit too much to take.

2828.31.text:
And so she duly named him in 
the House of Commons

2831.21.text: and he was stripped of his job.

2833.66.text: I think he wasn't stripped of his professorship,

2836.37.text: but stripped of his knighthood certainly

2838.68.text:
because he didn't carry out any 
great favours for this country.

2845.33.text:
Later, after the war, 
my father stayed in MI5.

2851.48.text: He kept eyes on any subversive organisation,

2856.92.text:
where you were worried they were 
going to use force.

2859.75.text: The Angry Brigade, little remembered now,

2861.92.text: but they came before the IRA,

2863.67.text:
and they too used bombs to try and 
create economic damage.

2867.73.text:
In fact, they were never responsible 
for any deaths.

2870.04.text:
It was the IRA who let off so many 
more bombs that

2872.78.text:
they did kill quite a lot of civilians, 
as I am sure you know.

2876.08.text: But he also kept an eye on anti-Vietnam demonstrations.

2881.13.text:
This is one of them, the famous one 
in Grosvenor Square.

2883.67.text:
And perhaps you can recognise 
the man with the moustache –

2889.61.text: And the young lady, Vanessa Redgrave,

2894.62.text:
The thing that my father told me 
when I interviewed him

2897.58.text:
and did a video interview with him 
shortly before he died,

2900.51.text:
was that when that demonstration 
was actually taking place,

2903.50.text:
it was led by a chief superintendant 
from Scotland Yard

2907.19.text:
who had infiltrated the whole group, 
and this never came out.

2911.26.text: And I wrote to Tariq Ali and said,

2913.53.text: 'Is that likely to be true?' And he said...

2916.01.text:
I could tell you afterwards in the questions
perhaps what he said,

2918.49.text: but he thought it might have been a splinter...

2920.65.text:
He said there was a splinter group 
in that demonstration

2922.63.text:
that went off and started playing football
with the police,

2925.39.text: which was perhaps a little bit of a giveaway.

2929.58.text:
You might think as my father 
was in charge of

2931.79.text:
the Russian department of MI5 
from 1945 until 1951

2936.27.text:
that with so many spies being revealed 
his own job

2939.13.text: might have been slightly on the cards.

2941.38.text:
But he spotted this woman, 
a lady called Jenifer Hart,

2944.81.text: married to the Professor of Law at Oxford.

2947.81.text: And she wrote a book about her life

2952.70.text: and she did work for MI5 for a short time.

2955.70.text:
And it's rather intriguing that she has this
title of her book,

2959.79.text: 'Ask Me No More', which often implies:

2962.22.text:
don't ask me too much or 
I might give something away.

2965.64.text:
And in fact my father was 
very suspicious of her.

2968.34.text:
Nobody else in the Office thought she could
have been a Communist.

2970.63.text: It eventually turned out she had been

2972.54.text: a member of the Communist Party since 1935,

2976.68.text:
even from her husband who was working 
in Bletchley Park at the time.

2980.69.text:
So he was quite horrified to 
find this had happened.

2983.08.text: And she was never actually charged,

2985.77.text:
but most experts now think 
she was also a spy for Russia.

2989.34.text:
Because my father spotted her 
he was allowed to carry on.

And in fact in 1957 he was sent out

2995.97.text: and there's his call sign there.

what the amateur radio people sent

based in Dulwich where he was
